title: Pics: The sleek new look of Formula 1 in 2017
text:
F1: Sauber team reveals the C36-Ferrari for the 2017 season February 21, 2017 1:51pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS THIS is our first good look at what Formula 1 cars will look like in 2017 ‚Äî and it‚Äôs hard not to like what you see. 
The Sauber team revealed images of its brand new Sauber C36-Ferrari overnight, becoming the first squad to show off photos of its actual car rather than renders. 
The Swiss team enters 2017 in its healthiest financial state in recent years after its purchase by investment group Longbow Finance last July. 
SCHEDULE: Your guide to Formula 1‚Äôs 2017 car launches 
On the driver front, Marcus Ericsson will be joined by Pascal Wehrlein in 2017 ‚Äî although not until the Mercedes protege recovers from a back injury incurred in a crash at the Race of Champions. Ferrari junior driver Antonio Giovinazzi will perform test duties in his place next week. The 2016 Sauber C36 ‚Äî Ferrari Formula 1 car. Source: Supplied 
ALL NEW CAR FOR ALL NEW RULES The new rules for F1 in 2017 mean not a single piece of last year‚Äôs Sauber can be used on this year‚Äôs car. 
The bigger wings and tyres shaped the design team‚Äôs philosophy with the C36, seeking to reduce the drag coefficient of the chassis. The 2016 Sauber C36 ‚Äî Ferrari Formula 1 car. Source: Supplied 
‚ÄúThe aero concept includes the optimisation of the front and rear wings and the underfloor. The radiator, the sidepods and the bodywork were designed to be as slim as possible,‚Äù the team stated. The 2017 Sauber C36 ‚Äî Ferrari Formula 1 car. Source: Supplied 
‚ÄúClear progress was also achieved in terms of additional downforce. The key here is to keep downforce, which is generated via driving, and remain stable in various track sections. 
Sauber technical director Jorg Zander added: ‚ÄúWe put greater emphasis on aerodynamic stability as opposed to maximising downforce.‚Äù The 2016 Sauber C36 ‚Äî Ferrari Formula 1 car. Source: Supplied 
RETRO STYLING The shape of the new generation of cars is a visual hybrid of the machines from the 1990s and 2000s: wide tyres on wide-track suspension, tucked neatly behind and ahead of wide, low-slung front and rear wings. 
But fans on social media took the retro look a step further. 
The team‚Äôs new but largely sponsorless blue, white and gold livery ‚Äî marking the team‚Äôs 25th season in F1 ‚Äî saw some draw an instant parallel with the now-defunct Ligier team.
